page.title: 12LOCAL HISTORY (CONTINUED)
page.content: Many old buildings still exist for example St. Mary's Church (Quarry St.) constructed in the 11th to 13th centuries, Holy Trinity Church (rebuilt in the mid 18th century), Abbots Hospital and the Guildhall. In 1651 the R. Wey was canalised to become The Wey Navigation and was used for transporting many types of products. It is now owned by The National Trust. The railway in Guildford dates from 1845 when the main line from London was extended from Woking, and the main line station was opened. By 1870 commuting to London was a well established practice. Between 1740 and 1840 the population doubled and in the late 19th century it grew threefold: most of the increase has been attributed to immigration. The pattern of growth continues today. {J. Speake
